title: Pediatric Appendicitis
diagnosis_topic: Inflamed appendix causing acute abdominal pain in a child
setup_script: A 10-year-old girl presents with 24 hours of abdominal pain that started periumbilically and migrated to the right lower quadrant. She has low-grade fever and anorexia.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 110/65 mmHg, HR 105 bpm, RR 22/min, Temp 38 C.
Tenderness at McBurney's point with rebound and guarding; Rovsing sign positive.
WBC 15 K/uL with left shift, CRP elevated; urinalysis normal.
Non-compressible tubular structure 8 mm in diameter with periappendiceal fluid, confirming appendicitis.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If ultrasound equivocal and patient stable
dynamic_flow.reply: Consider MRI or CT scan to avoid radiation if available.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident places patient NPO, starts IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics
dynamic_flow.reply: Begin piperacillin-tazobactam or ceftriaxone plus metronidazole.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident consults surgery for laparoscopic appendectomy
dynamic_flow.reply: Schedule operative removal; proceed urgently if perforation suspected.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If appendix appears perforated with abscess formation
dynamic_flow.reply: Consider percutaneous drainage and interval appendectomy after 6 weeks.
Appendix may perforate leading to peritonitis and sepsis.
Selected non-perforated cases may be managed with antibiotics, but recurrence risk exists.
Early ambulation, pain control, diet advancement and discharge when tolerating oral intake.
Explain signs of complications and the need for follow-up.

critical_decision_points: Evaluation of suspected appendicitis with history, exam and imaging
Initiation of NPO status, IV fluids and antibiotics
Decision-making regarding immediate surgery vs. non-operative management
Recognition and management of perforated appendicitis and abscess
